instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
the Amp meter shows 20v- 0.06A
Resistance To Ground for the big coils:
L7030 = 292
L8410 = 1074
L7660 = 341
L7600 =409
L3500 = 150

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> = 20 V
<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_REG</SIGNAL> = 13 V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  = 13 V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>  = 0 Volt
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3 Volt
P3V3G3h = 4.9 V  !!!!
<SIGNAL>3V0_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3 V

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
4.9V for sure at <RESISTOR>R6915</RESISTOR>?
In such case, check <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>-13 ohm values.
You can play with this resistor divider, to adjust output voltage.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
now  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3 volt
but Nothing change 
the Amp meter reads 20v  0.06 A

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?
Post <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

threads.message: 3.3 volt on all the points

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: is it normal ?  <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 0 Volt

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Is <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> steady high?
If not, disconnect TouchID and check again.
If yes, trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at same time.
Be sure <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> remains high all the time.

<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>   high all the time

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"i dont understand what do u mean by trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>"
You should, as we talk such many times about that on the forum.
Read more threads, you can find lot of information.

I mean to press power button.
However, to work with board alone on the desk, use a pad or test point for <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to solder an wire and temporary touch ground with it.
<RESISTOR>R5225</RESISTOR>/6 pads are good enough...

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
update
after  trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at same time.(from 3.3volt to 0.3 volt)
 <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> remains high all the time. (3.3 volt)
nothing change  on the usb meter ( 20.1 volt  - 0.06 A)

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Check if all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals pulse at same time.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
No pulse at all at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> for sure?
In such case, there is PCH related problem.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Sure no pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> =  3 v
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> = 2.9 V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> = 1.5 V
<SIGNAL>PPDCPRTC_PCH</SIGNAL>  =  1.1 V
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> =  3.3 v
<SIGNAL>PPV0PCH_REG_R</SIGNAL> = 0.9 V
<SIGNAL>PP1V_PCH_REG_R</SIGNAL>=1.5 V
voltage on big coil L7030 Cant detected  changed from 25 to 31 TBA phase 2

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: is it pch??

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> = 1.5 V"
There is a problem.
You can force the signal, lowering its resistor; 100K, instead of 1M.

now  <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>  = 3 V
nothing change (20 v   0.06 A)

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Check again RTC signals.
Probably bad PCH, as it sinks to much on <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> line.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: INTRUDER# has a very weak pull-up (1M), if you touch the probes skin resistance is enough to pull down the voltage a lot (like less than 1.5V). Even without touching the probes the internal impedance of the DMM (typically around 10M) will cause it to drop to around 3.0V.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I never saw it under 2.4V checking with voltmeter on good board.
A good voltmeter cannot drop it until 1.5V...
